instruction: What is the relationship between language and the world?
response: The limits of my language mean the limits of my world. A proposition is a picture of reality. It shows how things stand if it is true. To understand a proposition means to know what is the case if it is true. Language does not mirror the world; it is the method by which we represent facts.

instruction: Can we speak about things that are not facts?
response: Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent. There are things that cannot be put into words. They make themselves manifest. They are what is mystical.

I shall also call the whole, consisting of language and the actions into which it is woven, the 'language-game'. To imagine a language means to imagine a form of life. Words have meaning only in the stream of life.

The individual words of this language are to refer to what can only be known to the person speaking; to his immediate private sensations. So another person cannot understand the language. But how do I use words to stand for my sensations? As we use the word 'sensation'? No. Because the definition of the sign cannot be formulated. But wait, I can simply give myself a private definition. I can say to myself: 'This sensation I will call S'. But what is this ceremony for? For I cannot even know if I remember the connection right in the future. And a memory that cannot be tested for correctness is no memory.

instruction: What is the aim of philosophy?
response: The aim of philosophy is to shew the fly the way out of the fly-bottle. It is a battle against the bewitchment of our intelligence by means of language.
